title: Keeping Your Gut in Check
body:
**Overview:**
The gastrointestinal (GI) tract is a 30-foot muscular tube that breaks food into nutrients and fuels cells throughout the body. With such a complex system, digestive disorders are common: 60–70 million Americans experience conditions like gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), along with widespread issues such as bloating and stomach pain. Genetics, anatomy, diet, stress, and lifestyle all influence gut health.

**Lifestyle foundations:**
Routine schedules, balanced diets with smaller frequent meals, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep help manage many GI issues. Stress management is critical, especially for IBS. Research shows early life stress raises IBS risk, but confiding in trusted people and managing stress can lessen symptoms.

**Fiber and diet:**
Gradually increasing fiber (aim for 20–30 grams daily) supports constipation relief. Incorporate fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and nuts at every meal. Some fiber-rich foods—high FODMAP items such as certain fruits, vegetables, dairy, and wheat/rye products—can worsen IBS symptoms; healthcare providers may recommend low-FODMAP diets when appropriate.

**Gut microbes and immune ties:**
The gut microbiota aids digestion and may influence obesity, type 2 diabetes, IBS, colon cancer, allergies, asthma, and rheumatoid arthritis. Probiotics (live microbes in supplements or foods like yogurt) may prevent antibiotic-associated diarrhea or ease IBS symptoms, but optimal strains, doses, and patient profiles remain unclear. Emulsifiers in processed foods can disrupt gut flora and promote inflammation; minimizing highly processed foods supports gut balance.

**Partnership with providers:**
Effective GI care requires collaboration. Engage physicians who listen to your history and work with you to tailor routines that foster gut health.

**Wise Choices for gut health:**
- Eat slowly and chew thoroughly to reduce swallowed air and better gauge fullness
- Enjoy smaller meals to avoid overfilling the stomach and triggering reflux
- Limit late-night eating; GI activity is highest earlier in the day
- Manage stress through mindfulness, relaxation breathing, exercise, and routines
- Eat on a schedule to help the GI system perform consistently
- Discuss probiotics with your doctor if considering supplements to ease constipation or IBS

Balanced diets, stress control, and consistent routines, combined with clinician guidance, help keep the digestive system on track.
